newsitem.title: INDIA: India TELCO upbeat despite poor Q1 sales.
newsitem.headline: India TELCO upbeat despite poor Q1 sales.

text.p: India's largest truck-maker, Tata Engineering and Locomotive Company Ltd (TELCO), expects to overcome a first quarter slowdown and boost sales by 10-12 percent in 1997/98 (April-March), its chief said on Wednesday.
"Slowdown in industrial activity is usually a 12-month cycle," chairman Ratan Tata said, adding that he expected the Indian economy to show signs of revival during the second half of 1997/98.
Indian industrial production in 1996/97 (April-March) grew only 6.7 percent against 11.6 percent in 1995/96, official figures show.
Despite signs of deceleration in 1996/97, the economic scene showed some positive trends that would accelerate growth in 1997/98, India's central bank said last week.
The government said India's index of industrial production rose 9.8 percent in April compared with the same month in 1996.
"Certainly, no company can grow every year at the same pace," Tata said, in reply to a shareholder's query. "Some years may be good while some may turn out to be bad."
TELCO beat market expectations with a whopping 44 percent surge in net profit for the year ended March 31, 1997 to 7.62 billion rupees, from 5.3 billion the previous year.
Sales in the first quarter ended June 30 at 18.80 billion rupees, lower by more than 10 percent over the same period last year, he said.
Exports fell 38 percent to $17.74 million in the quarter, but the firm's construction equipment business grew 35 percent.
"The market has been quite tough since the second half of last year (1996/97) and it continues in the first half of 1997/98," Tata said.
"Infrastructure projects are starting to take place and some kind of uptrend in economic activity can be expected."
TELCO will spend 45 billion rupees in its projected capital expenditure plan over the next three years, Tata said.
He said TELCO had earmarked 17.0 billion rupees of these funds for a small car project.
Tata said about 55 percent of the 45 billion rupees would be raised through internal accruals and the rest by borrowings.

TELCO plans to launch a small car, tentatively christened the "Indicar", to take on the Maruti 800, India's largest selling car, produced by Maruti Udyog, a joint venture of Suzuki Motor Co. of Japan and the Indian government.
Small car production is expected to begin by the end of 1998. It will make 150,000 units per year at full capacity.
Tata said he expected the Indian small car market size to be 600,000 to 700,000 a year by the year 2000.
The total Indian car market is expected to grow to between 800,000 and one million by 2000, he said.
